lessons.title: Project Goal and Scope
masteryOutcomes: Choose an app idea that fits your API
Define in-scope vs out-of-scope features
List the minimum ‚Äúdone‚Äù feature set

lessons.title: UX vs UI
masteryOutcomes: Distinguish UI vs UX in plain terms
Identify 3 UX requirements for any CRUD app (loading, errors, empty states)
Add UX notes to the project plan (what the user sees)

lessons.title: User Stories
masteryOutcomes: Write 4-6 user stories for your app (list, detail, create, edit, login optional)
Keep stories small and testable
Prioritize stories (must-have vs nice-to-have)

lessons.title: Wireframes: Core Screens
masteryOutcomes: Create wireframes for 3-4 screens (list, detail, create/edit, login optional)
Label key UI elements (inputs, buttons, messages)
Ensure wireframes match your stories

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: App scope and feature set
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: You will be able to clearly define an app‚Äôs goal, in-scope vs out-of-scope features, and a minimal ‚Äúdone‚Äù feature set for a CRUD-style project.

lessons.title: Map Screens to Endpoints
masteryOutcomes: List your API endpoints (method + path)
Map each screen to the endpoints it needs
Identify which endpoints require auth (if any)

lessons.title: Data Flow Basics
masteryOutcomes: Describe one read flow (load list ‚Üí render)
Describe one write flow (submit form ‚Üí update UI)
Include loading/error/success outcomes

lessons.title: Vite Setup and API Base URL
masteryOutcomes: Create a React app with Vite and run it locally
Store API base URL in an env var (VITE_API_BASE_URL)
Confirm you can hit one endpoint from the browser, if needed you can disable auth for now

lessons.title: Why Routing Exists
masteryOutcomes: Explain what routing solves in a React single-page app (different URLs ‚Üí different screens)
Distinguish a ‚Äúpage‚Äù component from a reusable component
Identify which screens in the project should become routes

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Vite starter app setup
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: You will be able to create a new React app with Vite, configure an environment variable for the API base URL, and run the app locally. Output: A running Vite React app that logs the configured API base URL to the browser console.

Add navigation with Link and confirm it works locally

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Movie list delete flow
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Implement a delete flow with a button that confirms the action, calls a delete endpoint, and removes the item from the UI. Output: A movie favorites list where each movie can be deleted after confirmation and disappears from the list on success.

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Create a login UI that submits credentials, handles success and error responses, and stores a returned token in localStorage. Output: A login page that, on valid credentials, saves a mock JWT token and shows the user as logged in, or displays an error on failure.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Protected create route
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.

Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Implement basic route protection so that unauthenticated users cannot access a create page and are redirected or shown a message. Output: A small app where the ‚ÄúAdd Budget Item‚Äù page is only accessible when logged in, otherwise showing a ‚Äúplease log in‚Äù screen or redirecting.

lessons.title: Authorization Responses (401 vs 403)
masteryOutcomes: Distinguish 401 (not logged in) vs 403 (not allowed)
Show a clear UI message for each
Disable or hide actions when appropriate

lessons.title: UI Consistency Pass
masteryOutcomes: Make buttons and inputs consistent across pages
Use reusable components where helpful
Remove duplicated UI code

lessons.title: UX Improvements
masteryOutcomes: Add better empty states
Add success feedback such as a message or redirect
Prevent double submits by disabling during submit

lessons.title: Effect Dependencies That Make Sense
masteryOutcomes: Choose sensible dependencies for fetch effects
Prevent infinite loops from state updates in effects
Fix ‚Äúfetch runs too often‚Äù problems

lessons.title: Manual Testing Checklist

Include failure cases such as API down or invalid input
Include auth checks if applicable

lessons.title: Build and Preview Locally
masteryOutcomes: Build the app using npm run build
Preview it using npm run preview
Fix any build-only issues

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Sensible fetch dependencies in product list
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.

Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Configure useEffect dependencies so a product list fetch runs when appropriate (e.g., filter changes) without causing infinite loops. Output: A product catalog page that fetches items when filters or search text change, but does not refetch on every render.

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: Manual testing checklist design
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Create a structured manual testing checklist covering read, create, edit, delete flows, including negative and failure scenarios.

lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
